title: Rolling - car driving around a quarter-circle turn

content.description: A car driving on a test track is approaching a turn that is in the shape of a quarter of a circle, as shown in the top view of Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. As the car travels around the turn, the left wheels travel in a circular path of radius <math alttext="R sub L" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math>, and the right wheels travel in a circular path of greater radius <math alttext="R sub R equals eleven tenths R sub L" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>R</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>11</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math>. As shown in the side view of Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the front wheels and back wheels have diameters <math alttext="d sub F" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub B" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>d</mi> <mi>B</mi> </msub> </math>, respectively, where <math alttext="d sub B equals three halves d sub F" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>B</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>F</mi></msub></math>.
content.question: During the time that the entire car travels around the turn, what is the ratio of the number of revolutions of the back right tire to that of the front left tire?

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems
